title: Blue Candies
question_text:
Two AP Statistics students are doing a project regarding a certain famous chocolate candies. The company that produces the candies claims that $8\%$ of the candies are blue. The students want to investigate this and head to the large candy machine at their local mall. Each student inserts multiple quarters into the machine and get a sample of $30$ candies on each turn. They record the proportion of blue candies on each sample and create an approximate sampling distribution of the candies obtained.
The first student is confused when the graph of the sampling distribution after many, many trials does not model a normal distribution. What is the most important reason why the distribution is not normal?

choices.text: The sample size is not large enough
The number of expected success and failures are not large enough
The population is most likely not normal
The students did not select enough samples
The students selected too many candies per sample

solution: When dealing with sampling distributions, the shape is unknown at the beginning, but does approach an approximately normal shape if certain conditions are met. In this case, the student was surprised that the shape was not approximately normal. In order for the sampling distribution to be approximately normal, the expected number of successes and failures need to be greater than or equal to 1010. This is called the Large Counts Condition and must be check in order to use the normal approximation for the sampling distribution of sample proportions. Choice 'B" is correct.

distractor_explanations.A: Choice 'A' is incorrect. When dealing with proportions, the only way to tell the shape is the Large Counts Condition. You cannot use the Central Limit Theorem for n≥30n≥30.
distractor_explanations.C: Choice 'C' is incorrect. Even if the population is not normal, the sampling distribution can be normal if the Large Counts Condition is met.
distractor_explanations.D: Choice 'D' is incorrect. The students select many, many samples which would more than likely be enough to approximate a sampling distribution.
distractor_explanations.E: Choice 'E' is incorrect. It is reasonable that the students stayed under the 10%10% condition with a sample size of 3030 as it was noted to be a large candy machine.
